newsitem.title: USA: Argentine July industrial output up 7.0 pct - FIEL.
newsitem.headline: Argentine July industrial output up 7.0 pct - FIEL.

text.p: Argentine industrial output rose 7.0 percent in July from July 1995 and was up 4.5 percent compared with June 1996, said Argentine consultant firm FIEL on Wednesday.
"Overall the figures confirm the recovery of industrial production in Argentina," Fernando Navajas, chief economist at FIEL, told Reuters Financial Television from Buenos Aires.
Navajas said the current level of Argentine industrial production was within the range of 1994 figures.
Navajas said the industrial production data confirmed that the Argentine economy was on a path to recovery and indicated the manufacturing sector would continue to expand.
"We are noticing a normalization of industrial production in Argentina across the board," " Navajas said. "The numbers will not be very impressive, but they will show the recovery is firm."
He added that durables good data, which had lagged in the recovery, were starting to increase on a month to month basis.
He noted problems, however, in applying the industrial data to the overall economy, and forecast that Argentina's gross domestic product would expand in 1996 by about three percent.
Navajas said the major policy challenge for the government lay in the addressing the fiscal picture, that is, to increase revenues and also to control public expenditure.
"The governement and ministries have to show that they can manage the fiscal deficit and advance a line of reform," Navajas said.
